hook.headline: Your Acne Treatment Might Be Making It Worse.

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers fit an inflammatory acne pattern
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show red, inflamed bumps‚Äîpapules and pustules that are actively irritated. This isn't just clogged pores.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why spot treatments alone don't work**

Inflammatory acne involves bacterial overgrowth AND immune response. Surface treatments can't reach the inflammation happening beneath.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 2: 71% said new breakouts were less frequent
‚Ä¢ Week 4: 83% said existing bumps were calmer
‚Ä¢ Week 6: 79% said skin looked clearer overall

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers fit a comedonal (clogged pore) pattern
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show blackheads and whiteheads‚Äînon-inflamed clogged pores. The good news: this is the most treatable form.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why physical exfoliation makes it worse**

Scrubbing spreads bacteria and causes micro-tears. You need chemical exfoliation that dissolves the plugs.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 2: 68% noticed fewer new blackheads
‚Ä¢ Week 4: 76% said pores looked smaller
‚Ä¢ Week 6: 82% said texture was smoother

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers fit a deep cystic pattern
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show deep, painful nodules under the skin. These form when infection goes deep into the follicle.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why over-the-counter treatments fail**

Cystic acne sits too deep for topical treatments to reach. You need something that penetrates to the source.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 3: 64% said new cysts were smaller
‚Ä¢ Week 6: 72% said pain was reduced
‚Ä¢ Week 8: 69% said fewer new cysts forming

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers fit a hormonal acne pattern
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show breakouts concentrated on jawline and chin, often cyclical. This is driven by hormone fluctuations, not hygiene.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why cleansing harder doesn't help**

Hormonal acne starts from the inside. External treatments alone can't address the hormonal trigger.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 2: 58% noticed less monthly flare intensity
‚Ä¢ Week 4: 71% said jawline was clearer
‚Ä¢ Week 6: 67% said cycle-related breakouts reduced

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest fungal acne, not bacterial
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show uniform, itchy bumps‚Äîoften on forehead, chest, or back. This is yeast overgrowth, not bacteria.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why antibiotics make it worse**

Antibiotics kill bacteria but let yeast flourish. Many people with 'treatment-resistant acne' actually have fungal acne.

**What to do**

‚Ä¢ Stop all antibiotics (with doctor approval)
‚Ä¢ Check your products for oils/fatty acids that feed yeast
‚Ä¢ Start antifungal-compatible skincare

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest rosacea, not acne
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show flushing, redness, and bumps‚Äîespecially on cheeks and nose. Acne treatments can make rosacea permanently worse.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why acne treatments backfire**

Benzoyl peroxide and retinoids are too harsh for rosacea skin. They trigger more inflammation and broken capillaries.

**What to do**

‚Ä¢ Stop all harsh acne treatments immediately
‚Ä¢ Identify your triggers (heat, alcohol, spicy food, stress)
‚Ä¢ Start gentle, anti-inflammatory care

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers fit a folliculitis pattern
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show bumps at hair follicles‚Äîoften from shaving, friction, or bacteria. This isn't acne, though it looks similar.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why acne treatments don't clear it**

Folliculitis is an infection of the hair follicle. It needs antibacterial treatment, not pore-clearing.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 1: 74% noticed less irritation
‚Ä¢ Week 2: 81% said bumps were flattening
‚Ä¢ Week 4: 78% said skin was clear

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest keratosis pilaris, not acne
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show rough, bumpy texture‚Äîoften on upper arms, thighs, or cheeks. This is keratin buildup, not infection.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why acne treatments irritate without helping**

KP needs gentle exfoliation and hydration, not antibacterial or drying treatments.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 2: 69% noticed smoother texture
‚Ä¢ Week 4: 77% said bumps were less visible
‚Ä¢ Week 6: 73% said skin felt softer

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers fit a perioral dermatitis pattern
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show bumps around mouth, nose, or chin‚Äîwith the lip line usually clear. Heavy creams make this worse.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why moisturizers backfire**

Perioral dermatitis involves microbiome imbalance. Occlusive products trap moisture and feed the overgrowth.

**What to do**

‚Ä¢ Stop all heavy creams immediately
‚Ä¢ Check your toothpaste (fluoride can trigger this)
‚Ä¢ Switch to lightweight, non-occlusive care

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest milia, not acne
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show tiny white bumps that don't pop like whiteheads. These are keratin cysts trapped under skin.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why extraction doesn't work like with blackheads**

Milia have no pore opening. They need professional extraction or specific exfoliation to dissolve.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 3: 62% noticed bumps getting smaller
‚Ä¢ Week 6: 71% said some had resolved
‚Ä¢ Week 8: 68% said skin was smoother

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers fit an acne mechanica (friction) pattern
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show breakouts where something rubs‚Äîmask line, helmet area, chin strap zone, or sports gear contact.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why it keeps coming back**

Friction + sweat + bacteria = perfect storm. You need to address all three, not just treat the bumps.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 1: 78% noticed less irritation
‚Ä¢ Week 2: 82% said fewer new bumps in friction areas
‚Ä¢ Week 4: 76% said pattern was breaking

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers show a mixed or unclear pattern
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers don't clearly match one subtype. That's common‚Äîyour skin may involve multiple factors.
resultsCopy.body:
**What to do**

‚Ä¢ Start with gentle, broad-spectrum care
‚Ä¢ Track your triggers carefully
‚Ä¢ Consider seeing a dermatologist for clarity

Many people have overlapping patterns that need a multi-pronged approach.

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest pseudofolliculitis barbae (razor bumps)
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show ingrown hairs and bumps in shaved areas‚Äîespecially the beard, neck, or bikini line. This is hair curling back into the skin.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why shaving closer makes it worse**

Closer shaves cut hair below the skin surface, making it more likely to curl back and cause bumps.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 1: 76% noticed less irritation after shaving
‚Ä¢ Week 2: 82% said fewer new ingrown hairs
‚Ä¢ Week 4: 79% said skin was significantly clearer

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest bacterial (staph) folliculitis
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show pus-filled bumps around hair follicles that may be tender or crusty. This is a bacterial infection requiring antimicrobial treatment.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why regular acne treatments don't work**

Staph folliculitis needs antibacterial agents that target the specific bacteria causing infection.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 1: 71% noticed less pus and tenderness
‚Ä¢ Week 2: 78% said bumps were healing
‚Ä¢ Week 3: 83% said infection was clearing

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest razor burn irritation
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show redness, burning, and irritation immediately after shaving. This is mechanical irritation, not infection.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why it keeps happening**

Dull blades, dry shaving, or wrong technique cause repeated trauma to the skin.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Immediately: 89% felt relief with proper aftercare
‚Ä¢ Week 1: 84% said shaving was less irritating
‚Ä¢ Week 2: 91% said skin recovered faster

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest after-shave folliculitis
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show bumps appearing 1-3 days after shaving. This is bacteria entering micro-cuts created during shaving.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why it develops after shaving**

Shaving creates tiny openings that allow bacteria to enter follicles and cause delayed inflammation.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 1: 77% noticed fewer post-shave bumps
‚Ä¢ Week 2: 81% said skin stayed clearer longer
‚Ä¢ Week 3: 85% said the cycle was breaking

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest fungal (pityrosporum) folliculitis
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show itchy, uniform bumps on the trunk, often worse with sweating. This is yeast overgrowth in hair follicles‚Äîdifferent from face fungal acne.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why antibiotics make it worse**

Antibiotics kill competing bacteria, allowing yeast to flourish even more.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 2: 68% noticed less itching
‚Ä¢ Week 3: 74% said bumps were flattening
‚Ä¢ Week 4: 81% said skin was clearer

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest pruritic folliculitis of pregnancy
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show itchy bumps on the trunk appearing during pregnancy. This is a hormonal response that typically resolves after delivery.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why this happens during pregnancy**

Hormonal changes affect the skin's immune response and oil production, leading to follicular inflammation.

**What to know**

‚Ä¢ Usually appears in 2nd-3rd trimester
‚Ä¢ Typically resolves within weeks of delivery
‚Ä¢ Safe treatments are available‚Äîconsult your OB
‚Ä¢ Focus on soothing, pregnancy-safe skincare

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest perforating folliculitis
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show bumps with central plugs that the body is trying to expel. This is often associated with diabetes or kidney disease.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why this pattern develops**

The body attempts to eliminate abnormal material through the skin, creating distinctive bumps with central cores.

**Important next steps**

‚Ä¢ See a dermatologist for confirmation
‚Ä¢ Get screened for underlying conditions
‚Ä¢ Blood sugar and kidney function tests recommended
‚Ä¢ Treatment focuses on both skin and underlying cause

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest sycosis barbae (deep beard infection)
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show deep, painful bumps in the beard area that may weep or crust. This is a chronic staph infection requiring aggressive treatment.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why surface treatments fail**

Sycosis barbae involves deep infection of hair follicles that surface antibacterials can't reach.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Week 2: 64% noticed less pain and swelling
‚Ä¢ Week 4: 71% said crusting was reduced
‚Ä¢ Week 6: 67% showed significant improvement

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest folliculitis decalvans
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show scarring patches with hair loss, often on the scalp. This is a serious condition that destroys hair follicles permanently.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why early treatment is critical**

Folliculitis decalvans causes permanent scarring and hair loss if not treated aggressively.

**Important next steps**

‚Ä¢ See a dermatologist urgently
‚Ä¢ You may need oral antibiotics or other prescription treatments
‚Ä¢ Early intervention can prevent spreading
‚Ä¢ This requires professional medical care

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest pyoderma faciale (rosacea fulminans)
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show sudden, severe facial nodules and cysts with intense redness. This is a rare but serious condition requiring immediate treatment.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why this is urgent**

Pyoderma faciale can cause permanent scarring if not treated quickly with prescription medications.

**Important next steps**

‚Ä¢ See a dermatologist immediately
‚Ä¢ You will likely need oral steroids and isotretinoin
‚Ä¢ This is NOT regular acne‚Äîstandard treatments won't work
‚Ä¢ Professional intervention is essential

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest sebaceous hyperplasia
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show small, yellowish bumps with a central depression‚Äîoften on the forehead or cheeks. These are enlarged oil glands, not acne.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why acne treatments don't help**

Sebaceous hyperplasia is benign overgrowth of oil glands, not clogged pores or infection.

**What works for this condition**

‚Ä¢ Professional treatments: laser, electrodesiccation, or cryotherapy
‚Ä¢ Retinoids may help prevent new ones
‚Ä¢ Don't try to pop or extract them
‚Ä¢ They're harmless but can be cosmetically treated

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest acne keloidalis nuchae
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show firm bumps and scarring on the back of the neck and scalp. This involves abnormal scarring response to follicular inflammation.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why it forms keloid-like scars**

The body overreacts to minor follicular damage, creating excessive scar tissue that forms hard bumps.

**What worked for people with your pattern**

‚Ä¢ Avoid close haircuts at the neckline
‚Ä¢ Steroid injections may help flatten bumps
‚Ä¢ Laser treatment can reduce scarring
‚Ä¢ Early treatment prevents progression

resultsCopy.label: YOUR RESULTS
resultsCopy.headline: your answers suggest acne conglobata
resultsCopy.intro: Your answers show severe, interconnected nodules and cysts with tunneling under the skin. This is one of the most severe forms of acne.
resultsCopy.body:
**Why over-the-counter treatments fail**

Acne conglobata involves deep, connected lesions that require systemic treatment‚Äînot just topical care.

**Important next steps**

‚Ä¢ See a dermatologist urgently
‚Ä¢ You will likely need isotretinoin (Accutane)
‚Ä¢ This can cause significant scarring without treatment
‚Ä¢ Professional management is essential

questions.quote: I thought I just had bad skin until I learned about pseudofolliculitis. The right approach cleared my beard line in 2 weeks.

a.headline: We know you've been burned before.
a.body: That's why every order includes our 30-day guarantee. If it doesn't work for your pattern, you pay nothing.

b.headline: Your skin's safety matters most.
b.body: EMUAID uses natural ingredients with 50+ years of safe use. No harsh chemicals, no synthetic irritants.

c.headline: Skepticism is healthy.
c.body: Over 45,000 5-star reviews from people who felt exactly like you do right now. Your pattern has been solved before.

d.headline: That's exactly why you took this quiz.
d.body: We just analyzed your answers against 847,000+ cases. Your results page shows exactly what pattern you're dealing with.
